TITLE: Omicron Takes a Toll on Businesses, From Airports to Supermarkets
SUMMARY: Surging Covid-19 infections have prompted flight cancellations, store closures and increased overtime work.

TITLE: AT&T, Verizon Refuse FAA Request to Delay 5G Launch
SUMMARY: The cellphone carriers offered a counterproposal that would allow limited 5G deployments to move forward this week.

TITLE: A Booming Startup Market Prompts an Investment Rush
SUMMARY: Early-stage venture capitalists are now investing millions of dollars in companies before they even have a coherent business plan, while a growing number of VCs are saying that we are likely in a bubble.

TITLE: Tesla Reports 87% Growth in Annual Vehicle Deliveries
SUMMARY: The electric-vehicle maker’s expansion comes despite parts shortages and other logistical problems that have hamstrung the auto industry.

TITLE: Can Paper Replace Plastic? A Packaging Giant Is Betting It Can
SUMMARY: Environmental-driven shift is complicated by frequent higher cost of cardboard, and by carbon-footprint calculus. Kalamazoo paper factory is a big test of whether the flood of ESG capital can transform supply chains.

TITLE: Workers Should See Job Gains Even Amid the Latest Covid-19 Wave
SUMMARY: Economists expect the U.S. labor market to strengthen in the months ahead because employers still need a lot more workers.

TITLE: Headaches and Backlogs Loom as Tax Filing Season Nears Again
SUMMARY: The mid-April deadline is returning as the Internal Revenue Service tries to whittle down piles of paperwork.

TITLE: Economy Week Ahead: Eurozone Manufacturing, U.S. Jobs Report
SUMMARY: This week’s economic indicators will feature measures of U.S. and European manufacturing, the U.S. trade deficit and Friday’s much-watched employment report for America.

TITLE: Chairman's Resignation Hands Control of FDIC to Democrats
SUMMARY: Jelena McWilliams’s decision to resign as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. paves the way for Democrats to gain control of the agency’s agenda.

TITLE: 'Yellowstone' Is a Huge Hit That Started With Small-Town Fans
SUMMARY: Paramount Network’s cowboy soap opera caught on in smaller markets before hitting it big in major cities. Now it is the start of an empire.

TITLE: New Covid-19 Pills Carry Risks: What Patients Should Know
SUMMARY: Pfizer’s antiviral treatment can interact with other drugs in dangerous and life-threatening ways, and Merck’s isn’t recommended for pregnant women.

TITLE: Chip Makers Contend for Scarce Talent
SUMMARY: A limited supply of qualified workers poses a challenge as facilities are built around the world to bolster the supply of semiconductors.

TITLE: Pricey Chicken Puts Thighs on Restaurant Menus
SUMMARY: Dark-meat items are traditionally less popular, but restaurants are promoting them as short supplies have driven up the price of breasts and wings.

TITLE: U.S., European Factories See Easing Supply Strains, but Omicron Threatens Setbacks
SUMMARY: Factories in Europe and the U.S. reported a further easing of supply-chain problems at the end of 2021, although the rapid spread of Omicron could worsen shortages of labor and supplies.

TITLE: Economic Forecasting and the Goldberg Variations
SUMMARY: At best, economic predictions for the year ahead can be as outrageously elaborate as a Rube Goldberg contraption—and 2022 could be trickier than usual.

TITLE: Apple Becomes First U.S. Company to Reach $3 Trillion Market Value
SUMMARY: The iPhone maker’s shares passed the milestone when they topped $182.856 a share. The stock is up 38% since the beginning of 2021.

TITLE: Jury in Elizabeth Holmes Trial Deadlocked on Three of 11 Counts
SUMMARY: A federal judge instructed jurors in the criminal-fraud trial of the Theranos founder to continue deliberating after they said they were unable to reach a unanimous verdict on three charges.

TITLE: FDA Authorizes Pfizer-BioNTech Booster for 12- to 15-Year-Olds
SUMMARY: U.S. health regulators cleared use of a Covid-19 booster from Pfizer and BioNTech in adolescents 12 to 15 years old, expanding access to an extra dose that could bolster the fight against the Omicron variant.

TITLE: Tesla Opens Showroom in China's Xinjiang
SUMMARY: The auto maker, widely admired in China, is wading into a region at the center of a human-rights dispute that has entangled Western companies.

TITLE: Covid Brings America's Beer-vs.-Liquor Rivalry to a Head
SUMMARY: Brewers struggle to retain a dwindling edge, as spirits makers campaign to grab market share using canned cocktails to burnish their product’s reputation and lower taxes on it. “Alcohol is alcohol.”

TITLE: Steelmakers Dive Into Junk Business to Feed New Mills
SUMMARY: U.S. steel producers are buying up scrap businesses, seeking a steady supply of raw material from junked cars and manufacturing waste for new mills.

TITLE: AMC Entertainment to Refinance High-Interest Debt
SUMMARY: The movie-theater chain’s CEO Adam Aron says the company will work on shoring up its balance sheet this year by trying to restructure expensive debt the company took on to survive.

TITLE: Law Firm Sullivan & Cromwell Taps New Leadership
SUMMARY: New York law firm Sullivan & Cromwell named litigator Robert Giuffra and corporate lawyer Scott Miller together as co-chairs, at a time when many large law firms are thriving.

TITLE: GM, VW Build Up Their Battery Supply Chains Amid EV Push
SUMMARY: Auto makers are trying to control more of the supply chain for electric vehicles, forging new partnerships with raw-materials producers and investing in facilities that make chemicals for batteries.

TITLE: India Hits Apple With Antitrust Investigation Over App-Store Practices
SUMMARY: The probe into how Apple runs its App Store adds to a series of global regulatory actions against U.S. tech companies. India’s watchdog was responding to allegations by a nonprofit group that a 30% fee on content sold through apps stifles competition.

TITLE: Apple Briefly Tops $3 Trillion Market Cap
SUMMARY: The iPhone maker’s shares closed below the milestone after a 41% jump since the beginning of 2021.

TITLE: The Elizabeth Holmes Verdict: Theranos Founder Is Guilty on Four of 11 Charges in Fraud Trial
SUMMARY: The verdict caps the downfall of the former Silicon Valley darling who claimed to revolutionize blood testing.

TITLE: AT&T and Verizon Agree to New Delay of 5G Rollout
SUMMARY: The telecom companies said they agreed to delay their rollout of a new 5G service for two weeks, reversing course after previously declining a request by U.S. transportation officials.

TITLE: Grammys Mull Postponement as Omicron Spread Disrupts Rebound in Entertainment
SUMMARY: The Recording Academy hadn’t yet reached a decision Monday morning, according to a person familiar with the matter.

TITLE: Starbucks Imposes Vaccine, Testing Requirements for U.S. Workers
SUMMARY: The coffee chain is one of the first large restaurant chains to take such a step ahead of potential federal Covid-19 vaccination mandates for large employers.

TITLE: David Bowie's Music Catalog Is Sold to Warner Chappell Music
SUMMARY: The deal, with an estimated value of $250 million, includes all of the singer’s studio albums.

TITLE: Job Openings on Track for New High Ahead of Omicron Wave
SUMMARY: There were 12 million job openings in the U.S. at the end of December, according to estimates. And the number of available workers continues to lag behind job postings.

TITLE: Fed Weighs Proposals for Eventual Reduction in Bond Holdings
SUMMARY: Shrinking the central bank’s $8.76 trillion asset portfolio offers another tool to tighten policy at a time of high inflation.

TITLE: Monthly Child-Tax-Credit Payments Cease, Ending Cushion for Family Budgets
SUMMARY: More than 30 million households started getting the child-tax payment in July, with parents using the money on essentials like groceries and stashing it as emergency savings. Unless Congress acts, that stream of cash is drying up.

TITLE: Toyota Overtakes GM as Best-Selling Auto Maker in U.S.
SUMMARY: The Japanese auto maker outsold GM by roughly 114,000 vehicles in 2021. Tesla and Hyundai gained U.S. market share as the semiconductor disruption affected companies differently.

TITLE: CDC Backs Pfizer-BioNTech Booster for Immunocompromised Children
SUMMARY: The CDC expanded its recommendation to get boosters to children 5 to 11 years with weakened immune systems. It also said people who got Pfizer’s vaccine should get a booster 5 months later, down from 6.

TITLE: Evergrande Is Told to Tear Down 39 Buildings on Man-Made Island
SUMMARY: The embattled property developer released data showing its financial stress had largely halted sales of new homes and said it had been ordered to tear down dozens of buildings on an extravagant man-made island in southern China.

TITLE: Workers Quit Jobs at a Record Level in November
SUMMARY: The number of times workers quit their jobs reached a fresh high in November, while job openings also remained elevated in a tight labor market.

TITLE: Ford Doubles Production Goal for F-150 Electric Pickup
SUMMARY: Ford said the increased production plans reflect high demand for the model. Shares of Ford recently rose about 9%.

TITLE: Find Covid-19 Home Tests Using Online Product Trackers
SUMMARY: Stock-monitoring platforms check inventory at various retailers and send users alerts if hot-ticket items become listed as available to purchase. But using these services is only half the battle.

TITLE: Come the Metaverse, Can Privacy Exist?
SUMMARY: In immersive worlds, new technologies will siphon up data at an increasingly granular level—a person’s gait, eye movements, emotions and more—putting far greater strain on existing safeguards.

TITLE: U.S. Prevails Over Canada in Dairy Dispute
SUMMARY: Canada has until Feb. 3 to change policies aimed at shielding its dairy industry from American competition, or the U.S. can proceed with tariffs, after a ruling published Tuesday.

TITLE: Tencent Sells Roughly $3 Billion in Shares of Singapore's Sea
SUMMARY: The Chinese internet giant retains a 19% stake in the e-commerce and videogame company, whose value topped $120 billion recently.
